Suppose we are making an NMOS chip with \($ngatesM\) million gates, to run at a frequency of \($freqG\)GHz. Our process makes MOSFETs with a gate-source capacitance of \($Cf\)fF, and our pullups are \($RLk\)k\(\Omega\). The \(R_{ON} = $RON\Omega \ll R_L \), so we can ignore it. Suppose also that we chose to use a \($VS\)V power supply (a bad idea!).
What is the average static power, in milliWatts, that a gate in this process dissipates?
What is the average dynamic power, in microWatts, that a gate in this process dissipates?
Now, we have \($ngatesM\) million gates, so what power does the whole chip dissipate? (In kiloWatts.)
To put this into perspective, consider the Sun. The luminosity of the Sun (the total power output) is about \($lum \times 10^{26}\)W. The radius of the Sun is about \($radk\)km. Thus each square centimeter of the surface of the Sun is putting out \($radiationKwcm2\)kW/cm\(^2\).
But our chip is about a square centimeter; a difficult problem for cooling! We cannot make chips this way.
